question: The law of octaves asserts that every eighth element has comparable properties when grouped in increasing order of their atomic masses and is also known as:
solution:
• The law of octaves, which asserts that every eighth element has comparable properties when arranged in increasing order of atomic masses, is also known as Newland’s relation (d).
  • John Newlands proposed this law in 1865 as an early attempt to classify elements based on periodicity.
  • The other options refer to unrelated physical phenomena.

Additional Information:

  • Newland’s law of octaves was one of the first periodic classifications of elements.
  • It faced criticism initially but laid the foundation for the modern periodic table.
  • This law is significant in the history of chemistry for recognizing periodic patterns.

question: What will be the atomic number of an element X which is placed in period 2 and group 17?
solution:
• The element X placed in period 2 and group 17 of the periodic table is Fluorine, which has the atomic number 9 (d).
  • Group 17 elements are halogens.
  • Options 7, 8, and 10 correspond to nitrogen, oxygen, and neon respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Fluorine is the most reactive halogen and the most electronegative element.
  • It exists as a diatomic molecule (F₂) under normal conditions.
  • Fluorine is used in various industrial applications, including the manufacture of fluorides and refrigerants.

question: Identify the element one that does NOT belong to Group 1 of the Modern Periodic Table.
solution:
• The element that does NOT belong to Group 1 of the Modern Periodic Table is Hydrogen (c).
  • Although hydrogen is placed in Group 1 due to having one electron, it is not an alkali metal and has very different properties.
  • Sodium, lithium, and rubidium are all alkali metals belonging to Group 1.

Additional Information:

  • Hydrogen is a non-metal and exists as a diatomic gas (H₂) under normal conditions.
  • It can also show properties similar to halogens in some chemical reactions.
  • Group 1 primarily contains highly reactive metals with one valence electron.

question: Identify the last element from the fifth period.
solution:
• The last element from the fifth period of the periodic table is Xenon (d).
  • Xenon is a noble gas and occupies the last position in period 5.
  • Helium is in period 1, yttrium is earlier in period 5, and rubidium is the first element of period 5.

Additional Information:

  • Xenon has atomic number 54 and is chemically inert.
  • It is used in lighting, medical imaging, and anesthesia.
  • The fifth period contains elements with atomic numbers 37 to 54.

question: Identify the correct statement about Newlands’ law of octaves.
option_1: He started with the element having the highest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at thorium which was the 56th element
option_2: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at Sodium
option_3: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at aluminum
option_4: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at thorium which was the 56th element
solution:
• The correct statement about Newlands’ law of octaves is:
  • (d) He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at thorium which was the 56th element.
  • Newlands arranged elements in increasing order of atomic mass starting from hydrogen and observed properties repeating every eighth element, extending up to thorium.
  • Other options do not correctly describe his arrangement.

Additional Information:

  • Newlands proposed the law of octaves in 1865.
  • His classification was an early attempt to find periodicity among elements.
  • Although initially criticized, it paved the way for the modern periodic table.

question: Which of the following group elements are called chalcogens?
solution:
• The elements of Group 16 (a) are called Chalcogens.
  • This group includes oxygen, sulfur, selenium, tellurium, and polonium.
  • Groups 2, 17, and 18 correspond to alkaline earth metals, halogens, and noble gases, respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Chalcogens have six electrons in their outermost shell.
  • They commonly form compounds with metals and non-metals.
  • Oxygen is the most abundant chalcogen and essential for life.

question: What is the name of a metallic radioactive transuranic element with atomic number 101 in the actinide series, discovered in 1955?
solution:
• The metallic radioactive transuranic element with atomic number 101 in the actinide series, discovered in 1955, is Mendelevium (c).
  • Mendelevium is named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table.
  • Seaborgium, nobelium, and rutherfordium are other transactinide elements with different atomic numbers.

Additional Information:

  • Mendelevium was first synthesized by bombarding einsteinium with alpha particles.
  • It has no stable isotopes and is highly radioactive.
  • It is used mainly for scientific research.

question: Identify the element that does NOT belong to Period 6 of Modern Periodic Table.
solution:
• Period 6 of the Modern Periodic Table includes elements with atomic numbers 55 to 86.
  • Let’s verify the atomic numbers of the given elements:
    • Silicon (Si) – Atomic number 14 → Period 3
    • Tungsten (W) – Atomic number 74 → Period 6
    • Rhenium (Re) – Atomic number 75 → Period 6
    • Platinum (Pt) – Atomic number 78 → Period 6

Hence, Silicon is the only element in the list that does not belong to Period 6.

question: Lanthanides are often called:
solution:
• Lanthanides are the 14 elements from atomic number 57 to 71 (Lanthanum to Lutetium).
  • They are placed in the f-block of the modern periodic table.
  • They are called rare earth elements because they were first found in rare minerals and were difficult to isolate.
  • They are commonly used in LEDs, magnets, and glass polishing.
  • Most lanthanides form +3 oxidation state.

Additional Information:

  • Promethium (Pm) is the only radioactive lanthanide.
  • Neodymium is used to make powerful permanent magnets.

question: Which year was designated by UNESCO as the International Year of the Periodic Table (IYPT) to mark the 150th anniversary of the Mendeleev Periodic Table?
solution:
• UNESCO officially designated 2019 as the International Year of the Periodic Table (IYPT) to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Dmitri Mendeleev’s publication of the periodic table in 1869
  • This proclamation was made by the United Nations General Assembly and supported by UNESCO .

question: Which element in the modern periodic table has the same number of valence electrons as that of caesium?
solution:
• Caesium (Cs) is an alkali metal with atomic number 55, and its electron configuration ends in 6s¹.
  • This means it has 1 valence electron, like all elements in Group 1.
  • Potassium (K) is also a Group 1 element, with atomic number 19, and electron configuration ending in 4s¹.
  • Therefore, Potassium has the same number of valence electrons (1) as Caesium.

Additional Information:

  • Group 1 elements are called alkali metals, and all have 1 valence electron.
  • This common configuration gives them similar chemical properties, such as high reactivity with water and formation of +1 ions.
  • Examples: Lithium, Sodium, Potassium, Rubidium, Caesium, Francium

question: _________ is the heaviest naturally occurring element of the Periodic Table with an atomic weight of 238.
solution:
• Uranium (U) is the heaviest naturally occurring element in the periodic table.
  • It has an atomic number of 92 and a standard atomic weight of approximately 238.
  • Uranium is a radioactive element, and its most stable isotope is U-238.
  • It occurs naturally in Earth's crust and is mainly used as nuclear fuel.

Additional Information:

  • Heavier elements than uranium (like plutonium or americium) are synthetic and man-made, not naturally occurring.
  • Uranium is used in nuclear reactors and atomic bombs due to its fissionable property.
  • It was discovered in 1789 by Martin Heinrich Klaproth.

question: Which among the following is a noble chemical element of science periodic table?
solution:
• Helium (He) is a noble gas, which belongs to Group 18 of the periodic table.
  • Noble gases are known for their complete outer electron shells, making them chemically inert or non-reactive.
  • Helium has 2 electrons, completely filling its first energy level (1s²).
  • Other noble gases include Neon, Argon, Krypton, Xenon, and Radon.

Additional Information:

  • Noble gases are used in lighting, welding, and cryogenics.
  • Helium is especially used in cooling superconducting magnets and filling balloons due to its low density and non-reactivity.

question: Which artificial element has been provisionally researchers in honour of Nobel Laureate Glenn T Seaborg?
solution:
• Element 106 in the periodic table is named Seaborgium (Sg).
  • It was provisionally named and later officially recognized in honour of Nobel Laureate Glenn T. Seaborg, who contributed significantly to the discovery of transuranic elements.
  • Seaborg was the first person to have an element named after him while still alive, which was a rare honor.

Additional Information:

  • Seaborgium is a synthetic (artificial) element, not found naturally.
  • It is part of the d-block and belongs to the group 6 elements, along with chromium, molybdenum, and tungsten.
  • Being highly radioactive, it has no practical applications and is studied only in laboratory research.

question: Hydrogen resembles the properties of which two groups of the periodic table?
solution:
• Hydrogen is a unique element and is placed separately in the periodic table because it shows resemblance to both Group 1 (alkali metals) and Group 17 (halogens).
  • Like Group 1 elements, hydrogen has 1 valence electron and can form +1 ions (e.g., H⁺), just like sodium (Na⁺) or potassium (K⁺).
  • Like Group 17 elements, hydrogen can also gain one electron to form a hydride ion (H⁻), similar to halides like Cl⁻ or F⁻.
  • Therefore, it shares characteristics of both alkali metals and halogens, but fits perfectly in neither group.

Additional Information:

  • Due to this dual nature, hydrogen is placed at the top of the periodic table without a fixed group.
  • Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe.

question: Which element of group 13 is a soft metal with a low melting point (303k) and is widely used in doping semiconductors and producing solid-state devices such as transistors?
solution:
• Gallium (Ga) is an element of Group 13 in the periodic table.
  • It is a soft metal and has a very low melting point of about 303 K (≈30°C), meaning it can melt in the palm of your hand.
  • Gallium is widely used in the electronics industry, especially in doping semiconductors and manufacturing solid-state devices like transistors and LEDs.
  • Its ability to form compounds like gallium arsenide (GaAs) makes it extremely valuable in high-speed electronic and photonic devices.

Additional Information:

  • Gallium does not exist in free form in nature; it is extracted from bauxite and zinc ores.
  • It expands upon solidifying, similar to water.
  • It is also used in solar cells and thermometers as a non-toxic alternative to mercury.

question: Which law was based on notes of the music?
solution:
• Newlands' Law of Octaves was proposed by John Newlands in 1865.
  • He arranged the known elements in order of increasing atomic mass and observed that every 8th element had properties similar to the first, much like the octaves in music.
  • He named it the "Law of Octaves" based on the concept of musical notes (Sa Re Ga Ma Pa Dha Ni).
  • Though initially not accepted, it was an early attempt to classify elements based on periodicity.

Additional Information:

  • This law worked well only till Calcium.
  • Later, Mendeleev’s Periodic Law and the Modern Periodic Law gave a more accurate classification based on atomic number.

question: In which group are the non-metal elements placed in a vertical column on the right side of the periodic table?
solution:
• The non-metal elements that are most reactive are found in Group 17 of the periodic table.
  • This group is known as the Halogen group and is placed in a vertical column on the right side of the periodic table.
  • It includes fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At).
  • These elements have 7 valence electrons, making them highly reactive, especially with alkali metals from Group 1.

Additional Information:

  • Halogens readily form salts with metals (e.g., NaCl – sodium chloride).
  • They are used in disinfection, lighting, and pharmaceuticals.
  • Group 17 elements show typical non-metallic properties, such as high electronegativity and the ability to gain electrons.

question: Who conducted X-ray spectroscopic study of a large number of elements ad showed that the frequency of X-rays emitted by an element is related to the atomic number, Z rather than the atomic mass?
solution:
• Henry Moseley conducted X-ray spectroscopic studies on a large number of elements in 1913.
  • Through his experiments, he observed that the frequency of X-rays emitted by an element is directly related to its atomic number (Z), not atomic mass.
  • This led to the formulation of Moseley’s Law, which established atomic number as the correct basis for the arrangement of elements in the periodic table.
  • His work corrected inconsistencies in Mendeleev’s table, where elements were arranged by atomic mass.

Additional Information:

  • Moseley’s work gave rise to the Modern Periodic Law: “Properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic number.”
  • He confirmed the presence of gaps for undiscovered elements and predicted their atomic numbers.

question: In 1955, which synthetic element is provisionally named Mendelevium in honour of Dmitri Mendeleev, who created one of the first periodic tables?
solution:
• Element 101 was discovered in 1955 and was named Mendelevium (Md) in honor of Dmitri Mendeleev, the scientist who created the first widely accepted periodic table.
  • It is a synthetic element and does not occur naturally.
  • Mendelevium belongs to the actinide series and is a radioactive metal.
  • It was discovered by a team led by Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, and colleagues at the University of California, Berkeley.

Additional Information:

  • Mendelevium was produced by bombarding einsteinium (element 99) with alpha particles.
  • Being highly unstable and radioactive, it has no practical uses, but is important in scientific research involving heavy elements.

question: According to Mendeleev’s periodic table, what was the atomic mass of Eka-aluminum which was later replaced by Gallium?
solution:
• Dmitri Mendeleev, while creating his periodic table, predicted the existence of certain elements that were not yet discovered.
  • One such element was Eka-aluminum, named so because it was expected to appear one position below aluminum.
  • Mendeleev predicted its atomic mass as 68 and its properties.
  • This predicted element was later discovered and named Gallium (Ga) in 1875, and its actual atomic mass was found to be 69.7, closely matching Mendeleev’s prediction.

Additional Information:

  • Gallium validated Mendeleev’s periodic law and demonstrated the accuracy of his predictions.
  • Eka-aluminum showed similar chemical properties to aluminum, as expected.
  • This boosted the credibility of the periodic table and its utility in discovering new elements.

question: Which of the following statements is correct?
option_1: Atomic radius increases across a period and decreases down a group in the periodic table
option_2: Atomic radius decreases across a period and increases down a group in the periodic table
option_3: Atomic radius decreases across a period and down a group in the periodic table
option_4: Atomic radius increases across a period and increases down a group in the periodic table
solution:
• The atomic radius refers to the distance between the nucleus of an atom and its outermost electron shell.
  • Across a period (left to right) in the periodic table, atomic radius decreases because:
    • Electrons are added to the same shell
    • Nuclear charge increases, pulling electrons closer to the nucleus
  • Down a group (top to bottom), atomic radius increases because:
    • New electron shells are added
    • Outer electrons are farther from the nucleus despite increased nuclear charge

Therefore, the correct statement is:

(b) Atomic radius decreases across a period and increases down a group in the periodic table

Additional Information:

  • This trend is consistent with the principles of effective nuclear charge and shielding effect.
  • Elements like fluorine (small radius) and cesium (large radius) are good examples of this trend.

question: Which of the following types of elements is included in the leftmost group of the periodic table?
solution:
• The leftmost group (Group 1) of the modern periodic table consists of the alkali metals.
  • These elements include Lithium (Li), Sodium (Na), Potassium (K), Rubidium (Rb), Caesium (Cs), and Francium (Fr).
  • Alkali metals are highly reactive metals with 1 valence electron, which they readily lose to form +1 ions.
  • They are soft, have low melting points, and react vigorously with water to produce alkaline solutions, hence the name "alkali metals".

Additional Information:

  • Group 1 elements are never found in free state in nature due to their high reactivity.
  • They are stored under kerosene or oil to prevent reaction with air or moisture.
  • These elements show increasing reactivity down the group.

question: Which atomic number element of the periodic table is named after Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and the founder of the Nobel Prize?
solution:
• The element with atomic number 102 is named Nobelium (No).
  • It was named in honor of Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and the founder of the Nobel Prize.
  • Nobelium is a synthetic, radioactive element and belongs to the actinide series.
  • It was first identified in the 1950s by scientists in the Soviet Union and later confirmed by American researchers.

Additional Information:

  • Nobelium does not occur naturally and is produced in particle accelerators by bombarding lighter elements.
  • It has no practical uses due to its radioactivity and short half-life, but it is studied for scientific research.

question: Which of the following elements has the largest atomic radii?
solution:
• Atomic radius refers to the size of an atom, usually measured as the distance from the nucleus to the outermost electron shell.
  • In a period (left to right) of the periodic table, atomic radius decreases due to increasing nuclear charge.
  • In a group (top to bottom), atomic radius increases because new electron shells are added.
  • Among the given options, all are in Period 2, but Lithium (Li) is the leftmost and has the lowest nuclear charge, so it has the largest atomic radius.

Order of atomic radii (largest to smallest):

Li > Be > C > N

Additional Information:

  • Lithium (Li): Atomic number 3, radius ≈ 152 pm
  • Beryllium (Be): Atomic number 4, radius ≈ 112 pm
  • Carbon (C): Atomic number 6, radius ≈ 77 pm
  • Nitrogen (N): Atomic number 7, radius ≈ 75 pm

question: What is the total number of periods and groups in the Modern Periodic Table?
solution:
• The Modern Periodic Table is structured based on increasing atomic number and is divided into periods (horizontal rows) and groups (vertical columns).
  • It consists of 7 periods (numbered 1 to 7), representing the number of electron shells.
  • It has 18 groups, which represent the number of valence electrons in the outer shell (especially for main group elements).
  • Therefore, the correct structure is:
  • Period: 7, Group: 18

Additional Information:

  • Groups 1–2 are called s-block elements.
  • Groups 3–12 are the d-block (transition metals).
  • Groups 13–18 are the p-block elements.
  • The f-block (lanthanides and actinides) is usually placed separately at the bottom.

question: Identify the group of the periodic table to which cobalt belongs.
solution:
• Cobalt (Co) has an atomic number of 27 and is classified as a transition metal.
  • In the modern periodic table, cobalt is placed in Group 9 and Period 4.
  • Group 9 elements include: Cobalt (Co), Rhodium (Rh), and Iridium (Ir).
  • These elements share similar properties like forming colored compounds, variable oxidation states, and being good catalysts.

Additional Information:

  • Cobalt is used in making alloys, batteries, and magnets.
  • It commonly exhibits oxidation states of +2 and +3.
  • It is ferromagnetic like iron and nickel.

question: Who arranged the elements with chemically similar properties, such as lithium, sodium and potassium, and showed that the properties of the middle element could be predicted from the properties of the other two?
solution:
• Johann Dobereiner, a German chemist, proposed the concept of “Dobereiner’s Triads” in 1817.
  • He observed that certain groups of three elements (triads) like lithium (Li), sodium (Na), and potassium (K) had similar chemical properties.
  • He found that the atomic mass of the middle element (Na) was approximately the average of the other two (Li and K).
  • This was an early attempt to classify elements based on periodicity in their properties.

Additional Information:

  • Other well-known triads include:
    • Calcium, Strontium, Barium
    • Chlorine, Bromine, Iodine
  • Dobereiner’s work laid the foundation for future periodic classification of elements, eventually leading to Mendeleev’s Periodic Table.

question: Why are the outermost electrons lost easily down the group?
option_1: The elements are inert
option_2: The innermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus
option_3: The outermost electrons are closest to the nucleaus
option_4: The outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus
solution:
• As we move down a group in the periodic table, new electron shells are added to each successive element.
  • This means the outermost (valence) electrons are located farther from the nucleus.
  • The force of attraction between the nucleus and these outer electrons decreases due to increased distance and shielding effect from inner electrons.
  • As a result, it becomes easier to lose the outermost electrons.

Correct Answer: (d) The outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus

Additional Information:

  • This trend explains why metallic character increases down a group, especially in alkali metals.
  • Elements like cesium (Cs) and francium (Fr) lose electrons very easily.

question: Which element’s symbol is derived from the Greek name hydrargyrum, meaning ‘liquid silver’ – indicating its shiny surface?
solution:
• The element Mercury has the chemical symbol "Hg", which is derived from the Greek word "hydrargyrum", meaning "liquid silver" (hydor = water, argyros = silver).
  • This name reflects mercury’s shiny, silver-like appearance and its liquid state at room temperature, which is unique among metals.
  • Despite its shiny look, mercury is a toxic heavy metal and must be handled with care.

Correct Answer: (c) Mercury

Additional Information:

  • Mercury is used in thermometers, barometers, and electrical switches, although its use is decreasing due to health hazards.
  • It is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature (25°C).
  • Its Latin-based name explains why its symbol (Hg) doesn't match its English name.

question: Which element of Group 13 of the periodic table liquefies just above room temperature?
solution:
• The correct answer is Gallium (Ga), which belongs to Group 13 of the periodic table.
  • Gallium liquefies just above room temperature, with a melting point of about 303 K (30°C).
  • It is a soft metal and can even melt in the palm of your hand.
  • This unusual property makes it useful in temperature-sensitive applications.

Correct Answer: (a) Gallium

Additional Information:

  • Gallium is used in semiconductors, especially in compounds like gallium arsenide (GaAs) for transistors and solar cells.
  • It is also used in LEDs and thermometers as a non-toxic alternative to mercury.
  • Other Group 13 elements like Aluminum, Indium, and Thallium have much higher melting points.

question: Identify the group of the periodic table to which iron belongs.
solution:
• Iron (Fe) has an atomic number of 26 and is classified as a transition metal.
  • In the modern periodic table, iron is placed in Group 8 and Period 4.
  • Group 8 elements include: Iron (Fe), Ruthenium (Ru), and Osmium (Os).
  • These elements exhibit similar chemical behavior, such as forming multiple oxidation states and complex compounds.

Correct Answer: (a) Group 8

Additional Information:

  • Iron commonly shows +2 and +3 oxidation states in compounds.
  • It is the most widely used metal and forms the base of steel and many alloys.
  • Iron is essential for life — it is a key component of hemoglobin in blood.

question: Why does the effective nuclear charge experienced by valence electrons decrease down the group?
option_1: The elements are inert
option_2: The outermost electrons are closest to the nucleus
option_3: The innermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus
option_4: The outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus
solution:
• The effective nuclear charge (Zᵉᶠᶠ) is the net positive charge experienced by an electron in a multi-electron atom.
  • As we move down a group, new electron shells are added, increasing the distance between the nucleus and the valence electrons.
  • This causes greater shielding effect by the inner electrons, reducing the attraction between the nucleus and the outermost electrons.
  • Hence, the effective nuclear charge experienced by valence electrons decreases because the outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus.

Correct Answer: (d) The outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus

Additional Information:

  • Due to lower effective nuclear charge, atoms lose valence electrons more easily down the group.
  • This trend explains increasing metallic character and reactivity in alkali metals down the group.

question: How many electrons are there in the outermost shell of a group 16 element?
solution:
• Elements in Group 16 of the periodic table are also known as chalcogens.
  • These elements include oxygen (O), sulfur (S), selenium (Se), tellurium (Te), and polonium (Po).
  • All Group 16 elements have 6 electrons in their outermost shell (valence shell).
  • Their general outer electronic configuration is ns² np⁴, where "n" represents the period number.

Correct Answer: (d) 6

Additional Information:

  • Because they have 6 valence electrons, Group 16 elements tend to gain 2 electrons to complete their octet, forming -2 ions.
  • These elements show increasing metallic character as we move down the group.

question: What is the atomic mass of oxygen (expressed in ‘u’)?
solution:
• The atomic mass of oxygen is approximately 16 atomic mass units (u).
  • This value represents the average mass of an oxygen atom, primarily based on its most common isotope O-16.
  • Oxygen has an atomic number of 8, which means it has 8 protons and typically 8 neutrons, totaling 16 u.

Correct Answer: (c) 16

Additional Information:

  • The atomic mass unit (u) is based on 1/12th the mass of a carbon-12 atom.
  • Oxygen is a non-metal and an essential element for respiration and combustion reactions.
  • In molecular form (O₂), its molecular mass is 32 u (16 u × 2).
